These foreigners are wily and faithless. Never let down your guard, and may the Goddess of the Dawn protect you in Her mercy.<Prompt>
The king has taken a beautiful queen, and I think a splendid addition to the royal family is not far off. An heir, perhaps...<Prompt>
We people of San d'Oria, too, must ever look to the future. The Elvaan must never fall behind foreigners, in power or faith.<Prompt>
I understand, Your Grace.<Prompt>
Very good. Do well, Francmage.<Prompt>
Yes, sire! My life for the Kingdom!<Prompt>
As I thought, there is nothing here... Only barren wastelands as far as the eye can see.<Prompt>
But there is something wrong about this place, I can feel it. I don't think-wink we should leave Xarcabard yet.<Prompt>
I agree. My nose has never failed me, but I don't smell anything. That's not normal. Something really terrrible must've happened here a long time ago.<Prompt>
Ridiculous. We cannot base our decisions on your feelings alone. You can stay and look for whatever  terrible thing  is supposed to be here, but I--<Prompt>
Help! Come quick! Raogrimm and Cornelia, they--<Prompt>
Ulrich. What happened!.<Prompt>
We were attacked by fiends, and Raogrimm and Cornelia fell down a crevice...<Prompt>
Oh, no! Oh, no!<Prompt>
Grr! Where!.<Prompt>
This way!<Prompt>4
<Singular/Plural Choice (Parameter 3)>Raogrimm and Cornelia...where could they have gone.<Prompt>
We have to assume the worrrst. If I can't find them, no one can.<Prompt>
Why must Humes and Galka be so irresponsible!. It is their fault for wandering off without telling us!<Prompt>
There are too few of us left to continue. I say we go back. Besides, we would find nothing even if we stayed.<Prompt>
I second that. I've had enough of this crrreepy place anyway.<Prompt>
B-but, there are still places we haven't looked--<Prompt>
We have seen enough. There is nothing here but dust and ruins.<Prompt>
We accomplished nothing but losing two members of our party and wasting an extraordinary amount of time...<Prompt>
Yeah, you're right. This whole expedition was a failure. Let's head back tomorrow.<Prompt>
Ulrich. Tell me something... Was it really an accident.<Prompt>
What do you mean.<Prompt>
Is it not true that there is some...shall we say, tension, between Humes and Galka in Bastok these days.<Prompt>
Are you accusing me of something, Elvaan.<Prompt>
Hah! Calm down. I do not care if it was an accident or not. I care even less about your little country's problems.<Prompt>
Just...do not cause any more trouble with such trivial matters while I am around. That is all.<Prompt>
...<Prompt>
It is quite late to be up and about, Sir Francmage. Is something wrong.<Prompt>4
<Singular/Plural Choice (Parameter 4)>Ah, Courisaille. It's nothing. I could not sleep, so I decided to take a walk. Leave me; I am fine.<Prompt>4
<Singular/Plural Choice (Parameter 4)>Yes, sir.<Prompt>4
<Singular/Plural Choice (Parameter 4)>No! Not you.... Raogrimm. What do you mean!. He died in an accident! I know nothing!<Prompt>
Sir Francmage. Are you all right, sir.<Prompt>
Stop! Do not come any further! No, nooo--<Prompt>
... S-Sir...Francmage.<Prompt>

Twenty years ago, I worked in this very town with scientists from all over the world. We were trying to solve the hunger problem that plagued Vana'diel.<Prompt>
Koru-Moru! Now that's a name that brings back memories.<Prompt>
People say that we scientists are a strange bunch, but Koru-Moru...now he was a crazy one.<Prompt>
But even a weird one like him had a girl he loved. I'll never forget seeing him and Rasusu...<Prompt>
You say you're looking for Rasusu. Now why would a young <Prompt>.[lad/lass] like yourself want to do that.<Prompt>
I see. Koru-Moru's finally started to remember... Well, that's one box of memories that should remain shut.<Prompt>
If you promise to keep quiet on the subject, I'll tell you what I know.<Prompt>
Twenty years ago, the Rolanberry Fields were rampaged by those dreadful Crawlers. The problem escalated to the point where the people of Jeuno had nothing to put on their dinner tables.<Prompt>
One adventurer saw the problem that lay before Jeuno and began calling for volunteers to travel to the Crawlers' Nest and exterminate the queen.<Prompt>
Seeing that her research was going nowhere, Rasusu decided to take her chances and go along with the adventurer.<Prompt>
I tried to contact Koru-Moru, in hopes that I could get him to persuade Rasusu to stay in Jeuno. But at the same time, Windurst had its own problems, and I couldn't get ahold of him.<Prompt>
And then she went...and no one ever saw her again.<Prompt>
After the war ended, I tried writing Koru-Moru many times, but I could never bring myself to tell him the truth about his beloved Rasusu.<Prompt>
Windurst had been devastated by the Great War, and Koru-Moru had seen the devastation with his own eyes. I could not bear to be the bringer of any more tragic news.<Prompt>
Knowing Koru-Moru, the memories of Rasusu probably got lost in the back of his tiny little head...<Prompt>
You know Koru-Moru, so you can understand why I ask you to keep the truth from him--for his sake.<Prompt>
Twenty years ago, Koru-Moru and Rasusu worked side by side for the good of Vana'diel.<Prompt>
However, the terrible Crawlers pulled the young lovers apart. A sad, sad story, it is.<Prompt>

What do you wish to know about. <Selection Dialog>Nothing. Conquests. Conquest results. Donating crystals. Conquest points. The effects of controlling regions. Regions controlled by other nations. Regions under beastman control.<Prompt>

All three nations are striving daily to put more regions under their control. This is what we call  conquests.  You can take part in it and serve your country by defeating enemies while you have Signet cast on you.<Prompt>
Each region comprises several areas, and the nation that rids those areas of the most monsters gains control of the region.<Prompt>
Nations receive goods and resources from regions under their control.<Prompt>
So, the more regions we control, the richer our nation becomes.<Prompt>
Border guards are also placed in outposts within regions under our control. They are there to cast Signet on adventurers like yourself.<Prompt>
Once you have your nation's Signet, you will be able to acquire crystals from enemies you defeat.<Prompt>

Not only that, but you will also receive conquest points. You get more conquest points if you defeat enemies in regions that are not under your nation's control. These points can be used to purchase items from guards like myself.<Prompt>
So you see...conquests benefit nations and adventurers alike. We expect you to do your best to serve your country.<Prompt>

You can see the current state of conquests by selecting  Region Info  from the main menu. Conquest results in all regions are regularly recalculated, so you may want to check them from time to time.<Prompt>
Shops in our city will be selling different items according to our conquest rank. The Troupe Valeriano will also visit the nation that finishes first and bring a little joy to its citizens.<Prompt>
You can donate crystals to your nation once you achieve rank 2. Just trade them to guards like myself, and we will ensure they are sent to the proper place.<Prompt>
We would like you to donate crystals to your nation from now on. Just trade them to guards like myself, and we will ensure they are sent to the proper place.<Prompt>
You can acquire crystals by defeating enemies while you have your nation's Signet. Having Signet cast on you is also the only way of taking part in conquests.<Prompt>
Rank points will be awarded to you for each crystal you donate, and you may be offered new missions as your rank goes up.<Prompt>
You also receive rank points for completing missions. Complete missions and take part in conquests to raise your rank and serve your country.<Prompt>
You are awarded conquest points when you defeat monsters while you are taking part in conquests. Select "Region Info" from the menu to check your current number of conquest points.<Prompt>
You can purchase items from guards like myself with your conquest points, but be warned that the number of points you spend will be subtracted from your current total.<Prompt>

When conquest results are announced, you will be told which country controls the region you are in at that time. Sometimes regions may become neutral, or beastmen may even gain control of regions.<Prompt>
If we gain control of a region, border guards will be placed at its outposts to help adventurers like you.<Prompt>
Merchants will also be placed there, and goods from that region will find their way to the local shops here.<Prompt>
Gaining control of regions is the basic principle behind conquests. We need each of you to do your best, and bring our nation to the top of the ranks.<Prompt>
Of course, sometimes we lose regions to other nations...so we must try to take them back before the next conquest results are announced.<Prompt>
As an incentive, we will award you with more conquest points for defeating monsters in those regions.<Prompt>

But if we are allied with another nation, you will only be awarded the regular rate for defeating monsters in our allies' regions. On the other hand, we will award you with more points for fighting in the top-ranked nation's regions.<Prompt>
Our paramount concern lies in the beastmen gaining control of our regions. If too many of us are defeated in a region, the beastmen will gain control of it.<Prompt>
If this happens, not only is it a great blow to our pride, but you will be unable to acquire any crystals in that region.<Prompt>
The beastmen are a menace to all nations. If they rise to power, we must all unite and drive those vile creatures from that region.<Prompt>
We need you to bring supplies to the outpost border guards who are placed in regions under our control.<Prompt>
There is one outpost in each region. Select  Region Info  from the menu, and look for the areas with a small flag mark on the map. That is where they are.<Prompt>

Here are the supplies. Just give them to the guard at the outpost and your mission will be complete. Now, choose which outpost you want to go to. We give different rewards for each region, so choose carefully.<Prompt>

What would you like to know about. <Selection Dialog>Basic rules. Official/private matches. Flammen-Brenner. Flamme. Match score. Petras and quarrying. Sprint. KO. Return.<Prompt>
The basic rules of Brenner are as follows:<Prompt>
First, the participants divide into two teams. Each side's camp contains the same number of  Flammen-Brenner. <Prompt>
At the beginning of the match, half of each side's Flammen-Brenner will be ablaze with  Flamme,  or flame, while the other half will remain unlit.<Prompt>
Participants can seize a Flamme from the opposing side's Flammen-Brenner and carry it around the Isle.<Prompt>
The goal is to steal your opponent's Flamme and use them to light your side's Flammen-Brenner.<Prompt>
The side that succeeds in lighting all of its Flammen-Brenner will be declared the winner after a specified amount of time.<Prompt>
If neither side is victorious before the match ends, the outcome will be judged based on the score. The  match score  section of the rulebook contains more information on this subject.<Prompt>
Brenner is significantly divided into public and private matches. Official matches are held periodically according to level and feature general participation.<Prompt>
You cannot reserve the Isle when an official match is being held.<Prompt>
No items are necessary for participation, but a minor fee will be collected. You will be unable to participate if your level is too low.<Prompt>

The match outcome will be recorded unless the number of participants fails to exceed <Numeric (Parameter 0)> members, or if there are fewer than <Numeric (Parameter 1)> members in a match where the two sides' numbers differ. In such cases, the game will be considered a training match and will not be recorded.<Prompt>
Private matches require a reservation, and participation may be limited. The <Set colour #5>Master of Ceremonies<Set colour #1> (MC) can freely adjust the rules and control match proceedings.<Prompt>
LS Liga  is a form of private match. You can learn more about LS Liga by speaking to a Marshal.<Prompt>
A Flammen-Brenner is a device that contains a Flamme (flame). The Flammen-Brenner is covered by a grate that will open after taking a set amount of damage, exposing the Flamme.<Prompt>
The participants must utilize this chance to seize the Flamme before the grate recloses. Once the grate is closed, the Flammen-Brenner will begin recovering from the damage it has been dealt.<Prompt>
If you manage to open the opposing team's Flammen-Brenner and capture their Flamme, you should make haste to light one of the Flammen-Brenner on your side.<Prompt>
After a certain amount of time, the Flamme will burn out and the opposing team's Flammen-Brenner will be relit.<Prompt>
Also, please note that you cannot quicken your pace using any special abilities while you are in possession of a Flamme.<Prompt>
In the event that neither side fulfills the conditions for victory, the outcome of the match will be evaluated based on score.<Prompt>

Ten points are awarded to each side for every lit Flammen-Brenner, while one point is awarded whenever a Flamme is captured, used to light a Flammen-Brenner, or recaptured from an opponent. One point is also awarded for protecting the Flammen-Brenner for a certain period of time.<Prompt>

Like Ballista, <Set colour #5>quarry<Set colour #1> (/quarry) can be used while playing Brenner. Participants may use this ability to dig up <Set colour #5>Petras<Set colour #1> and temporary items.<Prompt>

However, unlike Ballista Petras, Brenner Petras have no effect on the match score. You can <Set colour #5>trade<Set colour #1> a Petra to a Pursuivant to recover your HP and MP at no expense to TP.<Prompt>
<Set colour #5>Sprint<Set colour #1> cannot be used while carrying a Petra. Also, please note that the <Set colour #5>scout<Set colour #1> ability cannot be used in Brenner.<Prompt>
Petras will be lost in the event of a KO, but can be carried over from one match to another.<Prompt>
The <Set colour #5>sprint<Set colour #1> (/sprint) ability can be used to increase the player's speed when not in possession of a Flamme or Petras.<Prompt>
In the event of a KO, you will be returned to your team's camp. However, recovery will take longer the more often you fall in battle.<Prompt>
In other words, you will receive a penalty if you fall immediately after recovering from KO. In addition, your TP will be reduced to zero and you will lose any Petras in your possession.<Prompt>

What do you wish to know about. <Selection Dialog>Basic rules. About the <Set colour #5>Petra<Set colour #1>. About <Set colour #5>Sprint<Set colour #1>. About <Set colour #5>Scout<Set colour #1>. About <Set colour #5>Gate Breach<Set colour #1>. About area-specific rules. About returning to battle. About special rules. Nothing at the moment.<Prompt>

Ballista is an exercise once used by the San d'Orian armies to train the Royal Knights in the art of the siege. The word  ballista  means  to throw a stone,  and the game has been a part of Vana'dielian military history for centuries.<Prompt>
The rules are simple. Ballista is played by two teams over a number of hours (Vana'diel time). The team with the most points at the end of the match is the victor.<Prompt>

Players from both teams must search for <Set colour #5>Petras<Set colour #1> that a <Set colour #5>Herald<Set colour #1> has buried in various locations across the battlefield. The players must then take these stones and throw them into targets known as <Set colour #5>Rooks<Set colour #1>.<Prompt>
These <Set colour #5>Rooks<Set colour #1> can appear in various locations around the battlefield, and both teams are allowed to throw their <Set colour #5>Petras<Set colour #1> into them.<Prompt>
Finally, a player's strength is adjusted depending on his or her level. It is felt that this ultimately allows for a more balanced battle.<Prompt>

<Set colour #5>Petras<Set colour #1> can be buried anywhere. Once a player believes he or she has found one, the <Set colour #5>Quarry<Set colour #1> (/quarry) command should be used to dig up the area at his or her feet.<Prompt>

Sometimes a player may find items other than <Set colour #5>Petras<Set colour #1>, such as potions. These <Set colour #5>temporary items<Set colour #1> can only be used during the current match (or Best of Three series).<Prompt>

Players can carry more than one <Set colour #5>Petra<Set colour #1>, but they cannot throw the stones away once they have obtained them. However, players will lose their <Set colour #5>Petras<Set colour #1> if they: (1) Successfully throw them into a rook. (2) Leave the area. (3) Are knocked out.<Prompt>

But don't forget, a player will be unable to use the <Set colour #5>Sprint<Set colour #1> command while in possession of a <Set colour #5>Petra<Set colour #1>. And, players can only use the <Set colour #5>Scout<Set colour #1> command if they carry one of the stones.<Prompt>
As one can see, careful planning and impeccable timing are the keys to victory.<Prompt>

All participants of Ballista will have the ability to use the <Set colour #5>Sprint<Set colour #1> command. This will temporarily increase one's movement speed, creating a better chance to find and obtain <Set colour #5>Petras<Set colour #1>.<Prompt>

However, remember that once a player has obtained a <Set colour #5>Petra<Set colour #1>, he or she will be unable to use the <Set colour #5>Sprint<Set colour #1> command. In its place, though, one may use the <Set colour #5>Scout<Set colour #1> command.<Prompt>
The locations of the <Set colour #5>Rooks<Set colour #1> are constantly changing. This makes it quite difficult to find the targets by just randomly walking about the area.<Prompt>

Communication with one's team members is, of course, one way to locate <Set colour #5>Rooks<Set colour #1>. However, another way is by using the <Set colour #5>Scout<Set colour #1> command. This will inform a player of the approximate location of the nearest <Set colour #5>Rook<Set colour #1>.<Prompt>

Finally, <Set colour #5>Scout<Set colour #1> can only be used when a player is carrying a <Set colour #5>Petra<Set colour #1>. Because <Set colour #5>Sprint<Set colour #1> cannot be used at this time, players must be weary of approaching enemies.<Prompt>
So, a <Set colour #5>Petra<Set colour #1> has been obtained and a <Set colour #5>Rook<Set colour #1> located. Now all that's left is tossing the stone in, right. Wrong.<Prompt>
There is one aspect of Ballista that has yet to be mentioned...and this is where the real battle begins.<Prompt>

To throw a <Set colour #5>Petra<Set colour #1> into a <Set colour #5>Rook<Set colour #1>, a player must first wait until the <Set colour #5>Rook's<Set colour #1> gate is open. This takes impeccable timing, as the gate is only open for a short while.<Prompt>

But not just anyone can score points this way. A player must first take down a member of the opposing team and achieve <Set colour #5>Gate Breach<Set colour #1> status. Only then will his or her shots count.<Prompt>
This extreme method of combat is what made the ancient game of Ballista famous, and transformed its participants into heroes.<Prompt>
Running about looking for stones is no different from a child's game of hide-and-seek. Knowing when to strike is what separates the men from the boys.<Prompt>

The following match types are area-specific: All or Nothing (one match) * Normal Items Allowed: Jugner Forest All or Nothing (one match) * Normal Items Restricted: Pashhow Marshlands Best of Three (three matches) * Normal Items Allowed: Meriphataud Mountains<Prompt>

<Set colour #5>Best of Three<Set colour #1> series rules are as follows: Winning a match will earn a nation one  match point.  The nation with the most match points at the end of the series will be declared the victor. Winning the third and final match and producing the high scorer will result in two match points awarded. This allows both sides the chance for  come-from-behind  victories.<Prompt>

Between each of the matches, a short interval will be implemented. During this interval, Invisible and Sneak will be cast on all participants. We suggest this time be used to discuss strategies with the other members of your nation's forces.<Prompt>

Players will be forbidden from using any items they bring to the battlefield. Only temporary items that are quarried may be used. A total of fifteen temporary items (though only one of each type) can be carried.<Prompt>
When this rule is in effect, all players will be presented with five complimentary temporary items at the beginning of the match.<Prompt>
For more information on temporary items, refer to the  special rules. <Prompt>

After being KO'd, if a player chooses to be revived at the spot he was defeated, 100% of all HP and 50% of all MP will be restored. In addition, the player will maintain 50% of the TP he had earned.<Prompt>
If a player chooses to return to their force's camp, HP and MP will be fully restored, but all TP will be lost.<Prompt>
Please note that many of the rules previously considered  special  have been fully implemented. Also, several new special rules have been added.<Prompt>

Learn about which special rules. <Selection Dialog><Set colour #5>Temporary items<Set colour #1>. Ballista Points. Scoring restrictions. <Set colour #5>Gate Breach<Set colour #1> radius expansion. Resistance to Sleep. Open entries. Minimum level restrictions. Re-entry restrictions. Participant & Rook numbers. Experience Points. Return.<Prompt>

Previously, participants in Ballista were required to use an item the moment they dug it up using the /quarry command. However, players can now stock these items as <Set colour #5>temporary items<Set colour #1> for use at any time during the match.<Prompt>

Players can hold up to ten <Set colour #5>temporary items<Set colour #1>, but only one of each type. If a player finds an item that they already possess, they must use it immediately or throw it away.<Prompt>

If players who possess ten <Set colour #5>temporary items<Set colour #1> find an item that they have not already obtained, they will also have the option to exchange it with one of their current items.<Prompt>

Also, players will not, at any time, be allowed to trade temporary items. However, there are items that can be used on other Ballista participants. Please note that players may not be able to use these special items as soon as they are quarried.<Prompt>
Finally, the Heralds will collect <Set colour #5>temporary items<Set colour #1> when the match (the third in a Best of Three series) has concluded.<Prompt>

Ballista Points are rewarded to each competitor based on his or her performance in a single Ballista match. The maximum number of points that can be accumulated per match is <Numeric (Parameter 0)>.<Prompt>

While it is taken into consideration, scoring <Set colour #5>Petras<Set colour #1> is not the only way to earn Ballista Points. Assisting allies and defeating members of the enemy forces can also earn a high score.<Prompt>

If there's someone who you feel a strong connection with, what can it hurt to ask them for their cooperation. You'll never know until you try!<Prompt>
Hello. Can I help you.<Prompt>
Hm. You're here about <Singular/Plural Choice (Parameter 1)><Singular/Plural Choice (Parameter 5)>6  .<Prompt>
I'm sorry you came all this way, but I've already been briefed on that particular topic.<Prompt>
Wait just a moment. Ah, now I remember you. Yes, I've been looking for you ever since our last encounter. Now, I need you in the field to help with my research...<Prompt>
Ah, forgive me. I was so excited to find the person I was looking for, I forgot to explain what it is I'm doing.<Prompt>
I've heard from a colleague that my research into Trust magic has earned the recognition of an academic organization.<Prompt>
They have even given me clearance to read their most confidential documents in pursuit of my research. Well, a portion of them at least.<Prompt>
However, when comparing that information against what I had gathered, I came across some interesting discoveries.<Prompt>
For example, I learned that you had defeated an unusual life-form considered to be the physical embodiment of the darkest parts of a person's soul.<Prompt>
Then it struck me--a new line of thought in my Trust magic research.<Prompt>
That's right. I'm researching the topic of a dark Trust magic!<Prompt>
How will you respond. <Selection Dialog>Dark Trust magic. I see where this is going.<Prompt>
Huh. You mean you don't know.<Prompt>
Oh you do, do you.<Prompt>
Well, allow me to briefly explain things just in case.<Prompt>
Currently, the Trust magic you use is based on light. It draws on positive forces such as trust, friendship, and <Prompt>.[brotherly/sisterly] love.<Prompt>
On the other hand, Trust magic based on darkness draws upon negative forces to generate its magic, much like how that woman was able to accomplish what she did.<Prompt>
Oh, I suppose I'm leaving out some rather important information. That is to say, an explanation of the negative aspects of mankind's darker side.<Prompt>

I'm basically referring to things like apathy, arrogance, cowardice, envy, and rage. You know, the darkest parts of one's soul. I believe that everybody harbors these feelings, at least to a certain extent.<Prompt>
In a sense, all of us are united by the darkness within our souls. Therefore, it only seems logical to infer that we have the necessary conditions to employ Trust magic from it.<Prompt>
All that remains is to try and elevate the darkness within the alter ego's soul and somehow link up with it...a type of bond all its own.<Prompt>

Although, even if we are unable to utilize the Trust magic, we have the <Singular/Plural Choice (Parameter 1)><Singular/Plural Choice (Parameter 5)>3   at our disposal. Intimate knowledge of your quarry should enable you to form a bond with them.<Prompt>
Which brings me to my request. I'd like for you to test your mettle against those unique forces. However, it cannot be any regular fight. You must really get to know your opponent.<Prompt>
I requested the A.M.A.N. to create a Records of Eminence objective for this purpose, so it should help you remain cognizant of your opponent during battle.<Prompt>
Hm. You want to know how to fight this particular opponent again. I think you probably know more about that sort of thing than I do.<Prompt>
You learn more about Trust magic, and I get further along in my research. That's what I call a  win-win. <Prompt>
I heard from my colleague that he obtained a rather unusual cipher. Perhaps you should see this through to its conclusion.<Prompt>
Ah, it's you again. It seems everything went rather well.<Prompt>
Judging by the magical aura you're giving off, I'd say we got the results I was hoping for.<Prompt>
Keep in mind that Trust magic research is an ongoing process. I must continue my efforts to unlock its mysteries.<Prompt>
I'm working on preparations for my next study. Please come by again later.<Prompt>
Hello again. I've finished making the necessary preparations. This is the data I'm searching for this time.<Prompt>
Thanks again for your help.<Prompt>
If the test results for this darkness-based Trust magic follow my hypothesis, then my next step will be to research Trust magic that combines the power of both light and darkness.<Prompt>
I believe Trust magic that combines the power of light and darkness no longer just gives rise to alter egos, but a unique form of existence.<Prompt>
An alter ego combining the power of both light and darkness... Just think of what this could mean!<Prompt>
Although, I'm currently suffering from a lack of research samples.<Prompt>
In order to successfully realize dark-based Trust magic, I tried replicating the connection that my research was based on, but it is not going so well...<Prompt>
If only I could get to the truth of the matter, it could be like a ticket to eternal paradise without the unfortunate precursor of dying first.<Prompt>

Completed objectives will vanish from your quest list unless they are repeatable. In the event that you wish to make room for different objectives, you will need to remove them manually.<Prompt>

Why I never! One with such a meager aura is not fit to be in my presence, let alone speak to me!<Prompt>
Well, it took you long enough to come speak with me! I have been sending furtive glances your way for what seems like an eternity now!<Prompt>
You know, you really should give up on helping Jamal with his utterly pointless research.<Prompt>
Like everything he does, it is destined to end in abject failure.<Prompt>
Hm. What do you mean it is none of my business.<Prompt>
Do you know who you are speaking to. I am Marjory, the most brilliant magician this realm has ever seen, and the foremost expert on Trust research!<Prompt>
I am somewhat surprised you did not already know that. At any rate, there is a certain matter I need your help with.<Prompt>
Will you help her. <Selection Dialog>Sure. No thanks.<Prompt>
H-how dare you decline my offer... You will come to regret this, I assure you!<Prompt>
I am pleased to see you make such a wise decision! Hehe... I cannot wait to see that buffoon Jamal choke on his own words!<Prompt>
Now then! Jamal likes to equate the darkness of alter egos to the root of all evil or some such nonsense, but as with most things, he could not be more wrong.<Prompt>
These are just my thoughts on the issue, but...<Prompt>
You see, unlike Jamal, I do not believe that Trust magic is something meant to be cast outwards from its user.<Prompt>
No, Trust magic is designed to look within us. In other words...<Prompt>
The alter egos take shape due to the power contained within a kind of unseen pipeline inside of us that conveys our feelings and thoughts to them.<Prompt>
That got me thinking! If one could somehow boost the amount of those feelings and thoughts being sent...<Prompt>
It could lead to the alter ego itself becoming even more powerful!<Prompt>
Hm. What do you mean you don't understand. You really are quite dense, aren't you.<Prompt>
Well, I am stuck with you, I guess, so you will need a few things if you are to help me with my research.<Prompt>
First of all, you will need this special diamond.<Prompt>
It is capable of detecting the feelings and thoughts you direct at the alter ego you are summoning.<Prompt>
This diamond then stores them within its crystalline confines.<Prompt>
Once it has gathered a certain amount of thoughts and feelings, it will change color.<Prompt>
So basically, I need you to use your Trust magic until you see the diamond change color!<Prompt>
To help you to that end, I have also prepared something else for you.<Prompt>
I ordered the A.M.A.N. to provide you with a list of Records of Eminence objectives!<Prompt>
There are three objectives for you to complete. You simply need to complete them all to collect what is necessary!<Prompt>
Ah, that reminds me. No matter what, you must not lose this diamond.<Prompt>
It is made from an extremely rare gemstone, so I forced my mother's jewelry shop to let me have it.<Prompt>
It was originally a rather unusual diamond that changed color whenever it sensed a change in the surrounding temperature.<Prompt>
I simply used a little magic to make some key improvements and recreate something from a legend I once heard in a faraway land!<Prompt>
Now then, let us begin the experiment!<Prompt>
Ah, there you are! I was expecting you much sooner. Hurry up and hand me the diamond already.<Prompt>
Hmm... Very well done. You have collected just the right amount of thoughts and feelings. Now, for just a touch of magic...<Prompt>
I-it's a staggering success! The thoughts have been imbued into the diamond!<Prompt>
Listen carefully. You simply need to use this diamond as a catalyst when invoking your Trust magic.<Prompt>
When you do, the thoughts sent to your alter ego when it manifests will be made even more powerful.<Prompt>
That power will then be sent to the alter ego when you attempt to call upon it.<Prompt>
As a result, the alter ego itself will also become stronger!<Prompt>
However, there is one thing you need to be careful of.<Prompt>
The more of these pipelines you use to call forth the alter egos, the weaker the effect of the catalyst will become.<Prompt>
I can see that your feeble mind is not comprehending what I am saying. Let me see, how can I dumb this down so even you can understand it...<Prompt>
If your party is made up of you and five alter egos, that means that five pipelines will be used, so each alter ego will only be slightly powered up.<Prompt>
And if your party contains you and one other member, along with four alter egos, that means there would be four alter ego pipelines and each one will be a little stronger.<Prompt>
Finally, if there are five in your party along with only one alter ego, that means there is also only one alter ego pipeline, so it will be made considerably stronger.<Prompt>
Do you understand now. Yes. I am glad to hear it.<Prompt>
Take note that the catalyst will not be effective unless you yourself are of considerable strength.<Prompt>
You must be strong if you wish to extract the power from the catalyst.<Prompt>
Now get out there and experience the fruits of my research for yourself!<Prompt>

Read the manual. <Selection Dialog>Sure. No thanks.<Prompt>
Mandragora Mania is a game in which you battle for jingly by moving your mandragora pieces to the goal.<Prompt>
Your goal is the <Multiple Choice (Parameter 0)>[red/blue/green] one on the right, while your opponent's is the <Multiple Choice (Parameter 0)>[blue/green/red] one on the left.<Prompt>
At the start of the game, three mandragoras each will be placed on the eight game areas, excluding the goal.<Prompt>
There are five starting placements (A through E), and you are able to select which one you would like to employ. The default setting is "Random."<Prompt>
This explanation uses pattern A, but the basic rules are the same regardless of the starting pattern.<Prompt>

The three <Multiple Choice (Parameter 0)>[red/blue/green] areas in front of you are yours,<Prompt>6<Singular/Plural Choice (Parameter 2)>the three <Multiple Choice (Parameter 0)>[blue/green/red] areas at the back are your opponent's,<Prompt>6<Singular/Plural Choice (Parameter 2)>and the remaining two are neutral.<Prompt>
You must choose one area--either yours or a neutral one--to proceed.<Prompt>
The areas are numbered from one to five starting from the left, and any mandragoras in the area you select will move.<Prompt>
Conversely, your opponent must select either a neutral area or an area that belongs to them.<Prompt>
From the right, those areas are numbered 6, 4, 7, 2, and 8.<Prompt>

For example, if you select Area 1,<Prompt>6<Singular/Plural Choice (Parameter 4)>one mandragora will move to Area 2<Prompt>6<Singular/Plural Choice (Parameter 1)>and one will move to Area 3,<Prompt>6<Singular/Plural Choice (Parameter 1)>and one will move to Area 4.<Prompt>
Note that the mandragoras will move from the back first--last in, first out.<Prompt>
You will receive points known as  jingly  each time one of your mandragoras reaches the goal.<Prompt>
You will enter your opponent's territory whenever you go past the goal.<Prompt>

If one of your mandragoras happens to reach the opponent's goal, the goal will be pushed back and your mandragora will return to your own area. You don't have to worry about your mandragora earning any jingly for your opponent.<Prompt>
The order in which players choose areas will be determined based on your turn settings. The default setting is random.<Prompt>
This explanation has skipped past your opponent's turn for demonstration purposes, but in the actual game you and your opponent will take turns choosing areas.<Prompt>
However, if the last mandragora to move reaches the goal, you will get to take an additional turn.<Prompt>
Mandragoras are a very diverse species, and the amount of jingly you earn is determined by the species of mandragora that crosses into the goal.<Prompt>
Adenium and citrullus: 3 jingly (first player)/4 jingly (second player).<Prompt>
Korrigan and pachypodium: 2 jingly (first player)/3 jingly (second player).<Prompt>
Standard mandragoras: 1 jingly (both players).<Prompt>
The game is over when either you or your opponent no longer has any mandragoras that can move.<Prompt>
The player who has the most jingly at that point will be declared the winner.<Prompt>
The key to victory lies in taking advantage of the various mandragora subspecies bonuses while claiming multiple turns in a row.<Prompt>
